text: At 1:01 p.m. local time, the aircraft turned east to repeat the loop to 85N.  All science instruments are operating nominally.
11:53 a.m. PST, the Global Hawk reached the northernmost point of this mission: 85N latitude,  then turned south.
RT @NASA: The Global Hawk is over the Pacific now on 3rd science flight. Goal: sample Arctic atmosphere north of Alaska up to 85 North.

retweeted_status.text: The Global Hawk is over the Pacific now on 3rd science flight. Goal: sample Arctic atmosphere north of Alaska up to 85 North.

text: Global Hawk Science Flight will now be taking off on Friday morning, due to weather.
Possible 28-30 hour science flight today for the Global Hawk, depending on the weather. Stay tuned!
The Global Hawk has broken the science mission duration record! They flew for 24 hr., 5 min. Next flight will be this week.
The Global Hawk is currently 800 miles west of Portland, on a north westerly track at 57,000 feet. Stay tuned for more updates!

retweeted_status.text: The DC-8 rolled out this morning for a local low-level mission to Greenland's Northeast Ice Stream.

text: @jdpsyntelos thanks! we are really excited about these science flights.
The Global Hawk landed safely at 2048 PT yesterday. The aircraft was in the air for just over 14 hours.
Successful flight! We sampled a polar vortex fragment in the Gulf of Alaska, and we underflew the A-Train constellation of satellites.

text: Global Hawk is still in the air! Scientists report that we have been sampling polar air for over 2 hours.

text: @ScienceMix Thanks for the RT!

GloPac Update: The scientists are looking at the data from Friday's flight & preparing for the first science flight later this week.
All science instruments were on board and collecting data. First science research flight will be this week.
GloPac test flight was a great success! The Global Hawk took off from DFRC Friday at 6:57am for a 6 hour flight.
RT @NASA: We are soaring for science today! NASA's Global Hawk is in the air without a pilot to explore our Earth. http://go.usa.gov/i4x

retweeted_status.text: We are soaring for science today! NASA's Global Hawk is in the air without a pilot to explore our Earth. http://go.usa.gov/i4x

text: This was a good flight & all objectives appear to have been met.
Global Hawk landed safely at 1318 PT, completing the first GloPac test flight.  The aircraft returned early due to weather.
@jdpsyntelos Thanks! The team is very excited about our first science flight.
Passing this test is a major accomplishment for the entire GloPac team.
This communication and function test (with engines running) is conducted on each payload configuration before flight.
GloPac successfully conducted a Combined Systems Test yesterday.
